titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, United States International Affairs Program (USIAP), Office Files of Enid C.B. Schoettle
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, United States International Affairs Program (USIAP), Office Files of Enid C.B. Schoettle FA604

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-12-16 03:18:22 -0500.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, United States International Affairs Program (USIAP), Office Files of Enid C.B. Schoettle

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files, and officers' papers were transferred to and accessioned by the RAC beginning in 2011.

The initial transfer of Enid C.B. Schoettle Office Files was ingested by the RAC as a part of Accession 2012:040. Later sets of Schoettle's Office Files were transferred to the RAC in 2019 and ingested by the RAC as Accessions 2019:031 and 2019:056.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collection contains the office files of Ford Foundation program executive Enid C.B. (Curtis Bok) Schoettle. From 1976 to 1993, Schoettle occupied a number of positions in the Foundation's International Affairs Program (IAP), a unit that was once organized under the Foundation's United States and International Affairs Program (USIAP). Schoettle served as Program Officer, Program Officer in Charge, and Director of IAP. Her work primarily focused on managing grants for international security and arms control research and initiatives.

Three types of files are found within the collection: 1) Meeting and trip files; 2) Subject files; and 3) Chronological correspondence files. Each of the different file types are organized and described in an individual series within the collection. The contents of these series document the progression of the Ford Foundation's grant funding priorities from the mid-1970s to the early 1990s within the field of international security. Correspondence, memos, grant proposals, and Recommended Grant Action records (RGAs) show the Foundation's support of research competitions for university-based research and training centers in international security and arms control, fellowships in international security and arms control and Soviet Union/Eastern European studies, and research and trainings focused on specific subjects related to international security. Major institutional recipients of these international peace related grants include the Brookings Institution, the Rand Corporation, the International Institute for Security Studies (IISS), and a number of universities like the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the University of California Los Angeles, and Indiana University. Within the collection, researchers will also find records that regard other aspects of the International Affairs Program's work that Schoettle supported such as grant funding for an internship program at Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty (RFE-RL), international economics research and projects, and the strengthening of European integration through assistance to the Centre for European Policy Studies (CEPS). The administrative tasks Schoettle took on as she gained more responsibilities in IAP are documented as well.
Common material formats found within the collection that have not been previously mentioned include papers, itineraries, publications, drafts, and invoices.

The collection consists of more than one accession of Enid C.B. Schoettle office files. Later sets of records transferred to and ingested by the Rockefeller Archive Center in 2019 (Accession 2019:031 and 2019:056) shared the same file types as the original material and were therefore integrated into the established collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection consists of 3 series that are based on file type: Meetings and trip files; Subject files; and Chronological correspondence.

A later accession of records containing Enid C.B. Schoettle's meetings files was added to where the original material ended in Series 2. Later accessions of records containing Schoettle's chronological correspondence was placed in Series 3 according to the files' date of origin in order to restore the chronological system of arrangement the records' creators intended.
The collection arrangement is as follows:

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas.

During the Foundation's first twenty years its major programs were in international economic development, primary and higher education, educational and public broadcasting, behavioral sciences, civil liberties, urban development, fine arts and the humanities. The Ford Foundation also partnered with the Rockefeller Foundation in supporting agricultural development in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Since the 1970s, the Foundation has also pioneered programs in women's rights, energy policy, micro-financing in under-developed countries, establishing human rights groups, and improving international HIV/AIDS education.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Enid C.B. (Curtis Bok) Schoettle (1939-2018) was an educator, foundation program executive, and leader in nuclear disarmament and international relations scholarship. She worked for almost two decades in the Ford Foundation's International Affairs Program (IAP) as a Program Officer, Program Officer in Charge, and Director. Most of her work at Ford focused on managing grants related to international security and arms control research and initiatives.

Schoettle graduated with a BA in History from Radcliffe College in 1960 and then received a Ph.D. in Political Science from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1967. Before joining the Ford Foundation in 1976, she taught Political Science at the University of Minnesota.

In 1981, Schoettle was promoted from Program Officer to Program Officer in Charge of the Ford Foundation's International Affairs Program. Her position then changed to Director in 1987. She left the Foundation in 1993.

Following her career at Ford, Schoettle joined the U.S. Government's National Intelligence Council as National Intelligence Officer for Global and Multilateral Affairs. She then occupied the position of Chief of the Advocacy and External Relations Unit of the United Nations Department on Humanitarian Affairs. In 1998, she became Consultant and Special Advisor to the Chairman of the National Intelligence Council. Schoettle retired from public work in 2004.

In addition to her work at the Ford Foundation, the United Nations, and the National Intelligence Council, Schoettle served as a member of a variety of organizations such as the Council on Foreign Relations and the Advisory Board of Women in International Security. She joined the Board of Directors for the Henry L. Stimson Center after her retirement. In 1996, Schoettle was recognized for her work on the National Intelligence Council by being awarded the National Intelligence Distinguished Service Medal.

physdesc.extent: About 4.25 LTR and 2 LGL size Hollinger boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains the meeting and trip files Enid C.B. Schoettle created during her time in the Ford Foundation's International Affairs Program (IAP). These records primarily originate from the mid-1980s to the early 1990s. They regard Ford Foundation program meetings, meetings Schoettle and the International Affairs Program organized for specific guests or topics, meetings organized by Foundation grant recipients like the International Institute for Security Studies (IISS), site visits to grant recipients or potential grant recipients, country visits, and other meetings, conferences, and workshops related to international security and arms control.

The series also holds a list of Grants and Projects out of Appropriation for October 1, 1965 to December 31, 1965. The list has a note, dated May 21, 1979, from a Joseph W. Currie on the front. The relationship between the list and Enid C.B. Schoettle's meeting and trip files is unclear. Perhaps, the list was placed in the original box that contained the meeting files by mistake.
The series consists of more than one accession of records transferred to the RAC from the Ford Foundation. A second set of meeting and trip files was added to the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains the subject files Enid C.B. Schoettle created during her time in the Ford Foundation's International Affairs Program (IAP). These records chiefly originate from Schoettle's time as IAP Director and regard IAP program reviews. The series also holds a few chronological correspondence files for consultants with whom Schoettle worked such as Johan Holst. These chronological files are not like the extensive files found in Series 3 for Schoettle's correspondence. They each only include one or a few pieces of correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains the chronological correspondence files Enid C.B. Schoettle created during her time in the Ford Foundation's International Affairs Program (IAP). The correspondence in these files chiefly regard grant proposals, grant evaluations, research competitions for grant funding, meetings, trips, conferences, program reviews, and administrative matters. Within these letters, Schoettle communicated with other IAP staff members, executives and employees in the larger Ford Foundation, grantees and potential grantees, consultants, and other academics and policy experts within the field of international security and arms control.

The series consists of more than one accession of records transferred to the RAC from the Ford Foundation. A second set of chronological files was integrated into the series based on the dates from which the material originated in order to restore the chronological system of arrangement the records' creators intended. Schoettle's correspondence from between 1979 and 1980 and from 1988 until her retirement are still missing from the series. Future accessions of material may add the files to the collection.
